Thinking Allowed.
Conversations on the leading edge of knowledge and discovery
with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome. I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Our topic today is remote viewing the future.
With me is Stephan Schwartz, an expert remote viewer,
a researcher. He is
a founder of the International Remote Viewing Association, also a founder of The
Society for the Anthropological Study
of Consciousness. He is the
author of many books, including
The Secret Vaults of Time and The Alexandria Project, both
dealing with remote viewing into the past.
Another book of his is Opening to the Infinite
and The Eight Laws of Change. Welcome, Stephan.
You’re mostly known for your work looking at
the past in remote viewing: archaeological
research... Yeah, I think that’s probably true…
Really where you made your mark in the world, but you've done remote viewing
into the distant future, into the year 2050.
Yes.
And that's what we’re going to focus on now.
I came out of six years as the editor of
one of the major magazines, journals,
about maritime and naval affairs…
Seapower. Seapower. And then
as the Special Assistant to the Chief of Naval Operations.
Then I did some work for the NSC.
NSC, meaning? National Security Council.
Out of that, this is back in the early 70’s,
came a real concern that nuclear war was
not only possible but
had a certain degree of probability.
People don't think so much about it now, but at that time,
and particularly in the military intelligence world,
the geopolitical world, that was a real issue. Well, when I was in
elementary school we were all taught, you know, if there’s a nuclear war,
we’re going to hide under our desks. Yes.
Exactly.
I’m not quite sure what the point was, but
in any case, yes,
there was this really strong concern.
People were building fallout shelters. It was a huge fad. Yes.
This was
the height of the Cold War and it was really quite scary.
So,
as you have said, I’m one of the founders of remote viewing
and I thought - although I had been
originally interested in archaeological
remote viewing -
I thought well, I don't see any reason
why you can't do this with the future.
The question was, well, how far into the future you can go.
Not because you’re limited by the remote viewing,
but because you wouldn't be able to understand what they were saying.
I thought about that and I thought, well, if I go too far into the future
I don't understand what they’re saying.
I mean, it's not that they can't do it,
but I won't understand what it means.
I spent several weeks thinking about this. My idea was
really, to be honest, is there a nuclear war?
So I finally settled on the year 2050.
In 1978 I started getting people to do remote viewings
of the same day, the same date, in the year 2050.
I continued from 1978 to 1996. In a particular
location? Wherever they were.
And I did this in Russia, Germany, France,
Jamaica, Mexico, Canada, the United States.
I had scientists,
engineers, government bureaucrats, housewives,
doctors.
Whenever I would go to a conference,
I would get either the
whole conference or individuals
to do this experiment. They weren't pre-selected for talent. Not at all.
No. Well,
I’ve been doing remote viewing research for almost half a century now.
I started in 1968, we
called it distant viewing. I knew that
the ability to do it is spread throughout the population, like any skill.
There’s a few people who are really gifted, there’s a few people who don't get it
and most of us are in the middle.
Since I have always worked on a consensus methodology
I
knew that if I got a whole bunch of people to do it,
that patterns would emerge in the data.
Now, some of these patterns are cultural.
There are cultural
motifs, memes, maybe that's the best word, that
influence remote viewing data. There are also personal
biases, but
overall, it would be very much like if outside
of this studio, if we heard a large explosion
we ran out and there’s a group of people -
what would we do? Well, you’d take people aside one by one. “What did you see? What
did you see? What did you see?”
Same thing policemen do, same thing intelligence
agents do,
same thing anthropologists do.
I thought, well, if I get enough people to do this
there will be dominant memes that will emerge.
And I presume there were.
Indeed there were.
It was not at all what I thought.
A typical one would be, “Jeff,
I’d like you to go forward in time to the same date as today
in the year 2050. You’re standing in front… you’re a lifesize -
that's important -
you’re standing in front of the place where you sleep.”
The thing about remote viewing is you must ask the questions
in ways that do not cue a particular response.
So, I don't say, “I want you to stay in front of your house,
where you sleep.”
Or, “your apartment where you sleep,”
because maybe in 2050 they don't have houses and apartments.
Maybe everybody lives in dorms, I don't know.
So I said, “You're lifesize,
it's the same date as today,
only it's the year 2050.
You’re standing in front of the place
where you sleep.
I’d like you to describe for me its exterior.”
You do that.
Then I would say, “OK.
I’d like you to enter this structure.”
Again, notice I don't say house,
I don't say apartment, I don't say co-op.
“I’d like you to enter this structure and
you’re standing in the first space
that you enter when you go through the door.
”I’m a little confused already, because does
it mean they’re in the place where they sleep
currently? Or, it presumes they’re going to...
No. Same date, in the year 2050… Not you, not
you… But who?
My presumption was,
because I believed that reincarnation was a valid area
of research.
Now, by the way, about 12% of people say, “Well, I’m not incarnate.”
And of course, a lot of people
when you did this study, was
decades ago, so 2050 was a little further…
Yeah, 1978 to 2050 was a long time, not
quite 100 years, yes… I mean, it's 33 years for us now. Yes,
but then it was almost a century.
We’ll get to that in a second because
that turns out to be quite interesting.
About 12% of the people said, “I’m not incarnate.”
I was completely unprepared for that,
so I then said once I had heard it,
“Alright, I want you to go
to someone who you feel empathetic with
and I want you to see all this through their eyes,
and I want you to describe them for me.”
But let’s keep going where we’re at. “So, OK,
you go to the place where you sleep.
Go through the rooms, describe them for me.
Is food prepared in the place where you are?
Go to that place, describe for me what you see.
Is there a place where food is stored?”
“Yes.”
“Can you access that?”
You notice I don't say open?
“Can you access that?” “Yes.”
“Alright, please do so.
What do you see?
What does it smell like?
What colors are prominent? Are there
shapes that are particularly important?
Go to the place where you sleep.
What does that look like?”
Then we go through that whole thing,
then I would say, “Alright,
I would now like you to go to the place where you
spend your waking hours and
you’re standing outside of it, you’re lifesize,
please describe it for me.
Now I would like you to enter that place.
What do you see?”
And that way we would go through all of it.
“I would like you to go
where there is an acquisition of material goods.
What does that look like?
How do you pay for it?
I’d like you to go to a place where
healthcare is offered.
What does that look like.”
So, all of that, so we go through a whole course of that.
So, that's a typical 2050 remote viewing session. I don't cue anybody
about anything. I have no anticipation
about what they’re going to say.
Anyway,
as with the remote viewing in the archaeology
work, or most of my remote viewing work,
not all of it, because
I did a whole bunch of just single
session laboratory studies. But in any case,
my applications work is all consensual.
As with that consensual work, just like I said, if
there was an explosion outside of this studio,
we ran out and interviewed people,
if we reconstructed collectively,
not everybody would see everything,
not everything they said would be right.
We know for instance from other studies that
men would be more likely to be able to give you the name of the car brand.
But women would be more likely to get the color right.
So, there are gender issues,
perceptual psychology. There are a lot of issues at work here.
Anyway, I took all of this data, transcribed it,
and broke it down into its concepts
so that if I said,
“The man sitting in the chair with the tweed jacket,” that's
five concepts not just a sentence.
So, we're talking about large masses of data,
and then you need computers to do this,
and you start processing it.
Well, what came out was not at all what I expected.
First thing,
let me say this, this was the headline, the takeaway:
every major consensual trend that the
remote viewers from ‘78 to ‘96 described
has come true.
Already?
Well, because when they would say,
“This was a result of something that happened 10 years ago,”
then I would say, “OK, well explain that to me.”
So, first thing, this completely freaked me out
because I was thinking in terms of Cold War. I’m in a…
we’re going to have a nuclear war.
So, the first thing I said was, “Is there a nuclear war?” “No.”
I said, “Oh, well, is the world safer?”
“No, the world is much more dangerous.”
“Why is the world much more dangerous?”
So, I said, “Why is the world more dangerous?”
“Because of terrorism.
Religious terrorism becomes a dominant activity
in the 21st century.”
I never thought about that.
We weren't worrying about religious
terrorists. We didn't even think about them.
So, second thing, “Well, who are the major forces
at that time in 2050?”
“Well, the Soviet Union has disapperaed.”
I heard that over and over again and I thought,
“What in the world are they talking about?
Martians came down and ripped the land up and
took it away?”
I mean literally, I
would read this stuff, it was sitting in my lap
reading, “The Soviet Union has disappeared.”
What in the hell does that mean?
Well, of course now it seems very clear.
At the time we saw the Soviet Union as this great
monolithic force in the world,
it never occurred to anybody - and I can say this
as a person who made his living doing geopolitical analysis -
nobody ever
in 1978 thought the Soviet Union was going to disappear.
It disappeared. So, to go back to, “The world is much
more dangerous becuase of terrorism” -
compeletly unprepared for that.
“Well, what other threats occur?”
“Oh, there are epidemics.”
“Could
you describe one of those epidemics for me?”
“Well, the first one
is a blood disease that comes out of Africa,
that crosses over from primates to humans and then
spreads over the world and kills millions of people.
So, I listened to this in 1978, 1979, early 1980,
and I go to a friend of mine who is with the NIH who is a hematologist.
I say to him, “Do you know anything about
a blood disease that crosses over from primates
that's
going to spread all over the world and kill millions of people?”
“No, there’s nothing. I don't know anything about that.” 1981 - the first
reports of AIDS come out.
That’s AIDS.
No anticipation of that at all.
When I would talk about how people travel,
they would say,
‘Well, actually people don't travel that much
in long distances.”
“Why not?”
“Well, because
they don't allow airplanes to fly as much because the emissions from the planes
do something to the atmosphere.”
That hasn't happened yet but you already see
in discussions of climate change, arguments about are we going to have to limit
air travel.
I said, “Well then,
if people can’t travel long distances, or don’t frequently do it,
how do they do it?”
They said, “Oh, well, you
put on this kind of apparatus and
in this apparatus you can project yourself
into this... well, I don't know how to describe it,
it's like a virtual reality,
only all your senses report
and you have meetings in there.
And so, that's how people do it. They don't
physically do it, they do it in this kind of
electronic space.”
Of course, we see that coming.
I have been interested in low energy nuclear reactions
as a result of the 2050 because
I was concerned already even in 1978 about carbon energy.
You’re talking about what
is sometimes called cold fusion.
Cold fusion, yes.
LENR.
So, what got me interested in it
was, people said to me,
“Well, they don't burn carbon anymore,
or not very much. There’s still a little of it, but
not very much.”
I said, “Well then, I want you to go to a place
where some conveyance exists
that would permit you to move locally.”
Again, not a car, not a bicycle, but
a place where a conveyance
exists that will allow you to move locally.
“How is it powered?”
“Well, you don't buy a car, you buy a chassis
and then you buy a superstructure that
fits, bolts onto it and you buy a kind of box
that powers it.” I said, “Well, what's the box.”
“Well, I don't know, it looks kind of simple,
it gets warm but not hot.
It produces more power than it takes.
I can't quite describe for you how it works
but you buy a little one to drive a car,
you buy a bigger one to power your house,
and an even bigger one to do a whole building.”
That got me interested in LENR
and I’ve been following that research ever since. It’s been controversial but it
looks like they're making progress. Well, SRI reports that they're making
good progress.
Mitsubishi reports they’re making progress, so
we’re going to see.
But in any case, we also now see,
I just read a paper just a few days ago about how
they’re going to manufacture chassis and then you can put whatever kind of car
body you want on top of it. Oh, how interesting.
So,
as I say, the interesting thing about this 2050 research
is that every trend they predicted, where there was strong consensus,
those have all happened.
The demise of the Soviet Union…
the disappearance of the Soviet Union, AIDS,
the rise of terrorism.
Oh, healthcare.
Again ‘
“Well,” I would say, “I want you to go to
a place where healthcare is provided.
I would like you to go inside. What do you see?”
“Well, it's very natural looking.”
And I said, “OK,
if a person were to have an infection what would they do?”
“Well, they don't do it the way that we do it now.”

Hm, we are watching that trend.
We are watching that trend happen, the
collapse of antibiotic medicine. A person just died a few weeks ago
of a superbug that no antibiotic would deal with.
Yes, that was in the news. It was a big story.
And we see this whole demise of antibiotic
medicine.
Again, ‘78 to ‘96, I’m hearing people
talk about the demise of antibiotics - what are you talking about?
So, the demise of antibiotic medicine.
Climate change - big, big deal on climate change.
“Well, in some places you have to live under a dome.”

multiple countries with all kinds of people.
They all tell the same story.
Social trends.
Social trends:
gender equality, marriage equality,

From gay to LGBT.
Demise
of antibiotics, lets see... The energy I mentioned.
Some people in places like
Las Vegas where we are now
living under domes because the heat is too great,

very important. In fact,

I
was just stunned. I was in Miami speaking at a conference

over the course of the

when I had been special assistant at CNO
